{{Refimprove|date=April 2008}} [[Image:De Groot academic genealogy.svg|thumb|240px|An example of an academic genealogy, the supervisorial relationship between Dutch [[topology|topologist]] [[Johannes De Groot]] and his namesake, also a Dutch topologist descended from the senior De Groot via four different paths of academic supervision]] An '''academic''', or '''scientific, [[genealogy]]''', organizes a [[family tree]] of scientists and scholars according to [[mentorship|mentoring]] relationships, often in the form of [[doctoral advisor|dissertation supervision]] relationships.
==Overview== The '''academic lineage''' or '''academic ancestry''' of someone is a chain of professors who have served as academic mentors or [[academic advisor|thesis advisor]]s of each other, ending with the person in question. Many [[genealogy|genealogical]] terms are often recast in terms of academic lineages, so one may speak of '''academic descendants''', '''children''', '''siblings''', etc.
Websites such as the [[Mathematics Genealogy Project]]<ref>{{citation | last = Carr | first = Sarah | date = August 18, 1999 | journal = [[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] | title = Retired Mathematician Develops a Family Tree of the Scholars in His Field | url = http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/recog/chronicle/chronicle.html}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Jackson | first = Allyn | issue = 8 | journal = [[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]] | pages = 1002–1003 | title = A labor of love: the Mathematics Genealogy Project | url = http://www.ams.org/notices/200708/tx070801002p.pdf | volume = 54 | year = 2007}}.</ref> or the Chemical Genealogy<ref>[http://www.scs.illinois.edu/~mainzv/Web_Genealogy/ Chemical Genealogy Database Homepage]</ref> document academic lineages for specific subject areas, while some other sites, such as [[Neurotree|Neurotree and Academic Family Tree]] aim to provide a complete academic genealogy across all fields of academia. However, not all links recorded in such databases are formal advisor-advisee relationships; for instance, the [[University of Cambridge]] did not require a formal doctoral thesis until 1919, and academic genealogies that include earlier Cambridge students tend to substitute an equivalent mentor.
Academic genealogies are particularly easy to research in the case of [[Spain]]'s [[PhD|Doctor degrees]], because until 1954 only [[Complutense University]] had the power to grant [[Doctorate]]s. This means that all holders of a [[Doctorate|Doctor degree]] in Spain can trace back their [[academic lineage]] to a [[Doctoral supervisor]] who was a member of Complutense's Faculty.
Academic genealogy may influence research results in areas of active research. Hirshman et al. examined a controversial medical question, the value of maximal surgery for high grade [[glioma]], and demonstrated that a physician's medical academic genealogy can affect his or her findings and approaches to treatment.<ref>{{citation | last = Hirshman | first = Brian R | date = January 4, 2016 | journal = [[Annals of Neurology]] | title = Impact of medical academic genealogy on publication patterns: An analysis of the literature for surgical resection in brain tumor patients | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ana.24569/abstract}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Academic genealogy of theoretical physicists]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== <!-- ONLY INCLUDE HERE LINKS TO GENEALOGIES OF SIGNIFICANT ACADEMIC DISCIPLINES. Genealogies of notable individuals should be linked to from the individual's WP entry. Similarly, genealogies of academic departments at individual universities do not belong here. --> *[http://academictree.org/ The Academic Family Tree]: A project combining academic genealogies of 38 (as of August 2015) academic disciplines **[http://neurotree.org/neurotree/ Neurotree: The neuroscience family tree] **[http://academictree.org/linguistics/ Linguistree: The linguistics family tree] *[http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/ Mathematics genealogy search (includes much of computer science and physics)] *[http://www.scs.uiuc.edu/~mainzv/Web_Genealogy/index.htm Chemical genealogy] *[http://www.chem.yorku.ca/NAMED/PDF-FILES/MasterList.pdf Scientific genealogy master list (two sections: Scientists Associated with Concepts in Chemistry & Physics; Scientists Associated with Discovering the Elements)] *[https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg14819995.600-on-the-origin-of-theses.html How to trace your scientific genealogy] *[http://philosophyfamilytree.wikispaces.com/ Philosophy Family Tree] *[http://nghiaho.com/?p=978 Automatic doctoral advisor genealogy diagram using Wikipedia] by Nghia Ho

{{Multiple issues|{{cleanup|date=May 2014|reason=Duplicate phrasing in lead and first section.}}{{COI|date=May 2014}}}}
'''Adolescent egocentrism''' is a term that [[David Elkind]] used to describe the phenomenon of adolescents' inability to distinguish between their perception of what others think about them and what people actually think in reality.<ref name=Elkindeia /> David Elkind's theory on adolescent egocentrism is drawn from [[Piaget's theory of cognitive development|Piaget's theory on cognitive developmental stages]], which argues that formal operations enable adolescents to construct imaginary situations and abstract thinking.<ref>{{cite book|authors=Inhelder & Piaget|title=The growth of logical thinking from childhood to adolescence|date=1958|publisher=Basic Books}}</ref>
Accordingly, adolescents are able to conceptualize their own thoughts and conceive of other people's thoughts.<ref name=Elkindeia>{{cite journal|last=Elkind|first=David|title=Egocentrism in Adolescence|journal=Child Development|date=1967|volume=38 | issue = 4|pages=1025–1034|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.1967.tb04378.x}}</ref> However, Elkind pointed out that adolescents tend to focus mostly on their own perceptions – especially on their behaviors and appearance – because of the "physiological metamorphosis" they experience during this period. This leads to adolescents' belief that other people are as attentive to their behaviors and appearance as they are of themselves.<ref name=Elkindeia /> According to Elkind, adolescent egocentrism results in two consequential mental constructions, namely [[imaginary audience]] and [[personal fable]].
==Mental constructions==
===Imaginary audience=== {{main article|Imaginary audience}} Imaginary audience is a term that Elkind used to describe the phenomenon that an adolescent anticipates the reactions of other people to him/herself in actual or impending social situations. Elkind argued that this kind of anticipation could be explained by the adolescent's preoccupation that others are as admiring or as critical of him as he is of himself. As a result, an audience is created, as the adolescent believes that he/she will be the focus of attention.<ref name=Elkindeia />
However, more often than not the audience is imaginary because in actual social situations always being the focus of public attention is not usually the case.<ref name=Elkindeia /> Elkind believed that the construction of imaginary audiences would partially account for a wide variety of typical adolescent behaviors and experiences; and imaginary audiences played a role in the self-consciousness that emerges in early adolescence. However, since the audience is usually the adolescent's own construction, it is privy to his or her own knowledge of him/herself.<ref name=Elkindeia />
According to Elkind, the notion of imaginary audience helps to explain why adolescents usually seek privacy and feel reluctant to reveal themselves – it is a reaction to the feeling that one is constantly under the critical scrutiny of others.
===Personal fable=== {{main article|Personal fable}} Elkind addressed that adolescents have a complex set of beliefs that their own feelings are unique and they are special and immortal. '''Personal fable''' is the term Elkind created to describe this notion, which is the complement of the construction of imaginary audience. Since an adolescent usually fails to differentiate his focus on his own perceptions and that of others, he tends to believe that he is of importance to so many people (the imaginary audiences) that he comes to regard his feelings as something special and unique.<ref name=Elkindeia /> This belief in personal uniqueness and invincibility becomes an illusion that he can be above some of the rules, disciplines and laws that apply to other people; even consequences such as death {{Citation needed|date=November 2014}}. Due to the existence of personal fable at some point, an adolescent tends to substitute the roles of an idol, a hero or even a god with his own image.<ref name=Elkindeia />
==Passing== Elkind believed that adolescent [[egocentrism]] was a temporary phenomenon that will gradually diminish as adolescents grow older. The reason of this, Elkind argued, was because after entering the formal operational stage, no new mental systems would develop. Therefore, the mental structures formed during adolescence would continue to function for the rest of the life span.<ref name=Elkindeia /> Accordingly, the two mental constructions that result from egocentrism, imaginary audience and personal fable, will gradually be overcome and disappear as formal operations become mature and stable.<ref name=Elkindeia />
===Passing of imaginary audience=== The imaginary audience, Elkind said, could be regarded as "a series of hypotheses" that an adolescent "tests against reality". Because the imaginary audience is usually constructed based on an adolescent's attention on his own perception, it will be gradually modified through communicating and reacting with real audiences. Eventually, adolescents will be able to recognize the difference between his own preoccupations and concerns of others.<ref name=Elkindeia />
===Passing of personal fable=== As to the passing of personal fable, Elkind's idea was drawn from Erikson's (1959) stages of psychosocial development. An establishment of what Erikson called "intimacy"<ref name=Erikson1959>{{cite book|last=Erik.H|first=Erikson|title=Identity and the life cycle|date=1959|publisher=New York: International Universities Press|location=Psychological issues v. 1, no. 1, monograph 1.|isbn=0393012468|pages=181–191}}</ref> could account for the elimination of personal fable, because during the process of establishing "intimacy", adolescents have to constantly adjust their imaginary audiences to the real ones. As a result, adolescents are able to see themselves in a more realistic way and to establish meaningful interpersonal relationships.<ref name=Elkindeia />
==Discussions== A lot of research has examined different dimensions of Elkind's concept of adolescent egocentrism, however, the findings have not well supported the concept.<ref name=Maholmes&Lomonaco>{{cite book|author=Smetana, J.G. |author2=VillaLobos M. |last-author-amp=yes|title=Applied Research in Child & Adolescent Development: A practical guide, edited by Maholmes&Lomonaco|date=2010|publisher=New York :Psychology Press|pages=187–228}}</ref> According to this research, the manifestation of adolescent egocentrism is not a normative developmental phenomenon that occurs only during adolescence, but varies across different contexts.<ref name=Maholmes&Lomonaco /> Main discussions from current literature focus on three aspects: whether adolescent egocentrism is age-related; whether adolescent egocentrism has association with formal operations; whether adolescent egocentrism weigh equally across genders.
===Not being age-related=== In his 1967 work, Elkind claimed that adolescent egocentrism emerges during early adolescence (age 11–12) and gradually dissipates throughout middle and late adolescence.<ref name=Elkindeia /> However, some findings from later studies indicate that this statement is not necessarily to be accurate. In 1986, Lapsley and his colleagues conducted two studies to examine the theoretical assumptions brought up by Elkind.<ref name=Lapsley1986>{{cite journal|last=Lapsley, D.K.|title=Adolescent egocentrism and formal operations: Tests of a Theorectical Assumption|journal=Developmental Psychology|date=1986|volume=22|pages=800–807|doi=10.1037/0012-1649.22.6.800|display-authors=etal}}</ref> In their first study they collected data from a sample that included 45 sixth graders, 39 eighth graders, 50 tenth graders and 49 twelfth graders. They used the Adolescent Egocentrism Scale (AES) developed by Enright et al. (1979, 1980)<ref name=Enright1979>{{cite journal|last=Enright, R. |author2=Lapsley, D. |author3=Shukla, D. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Adolescent egocentrism in early and late adolescence|journal=Adolescence|date=1979|volume=14|pages=687–695}}</ref><ref name=Enright1980>{{cite journal |author=Enright, R. |author2=Shukla, D. |author3=Lapsley, D. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Adolescent egocentrism-sociocentrism and self-consciousness|journal=Journal of youth and Adolescence|date=1980|volume=9|pages=101–116|doi=10.1007/bf02087929}}</ref> and paper-and-pencil battery of formal operations tasks developed by Lunzer (1965)<ref name=Lunzer1965>{{cite journal|last=Lunzer, E.|title=Problems of formal reasoning in test situations. In P. Mussen(Ed.), European research in cognitive development [Special issue]|journal=Monographs for the Society for Research in Child Development|date=1965|volume=30(2, Serial No. 100)|pages=19–46}}</ref> as measuring instruments to examine the correlation between adolescent egocentrism and formal operational thought.
If Elkind's assumption were right, the correlation was supposed to change from positive to negative as the grade increased and the magnitude of the correlation should decrease with age. The results of the study obtained only significant negative correlation in late adolescence and non-significant change in the magnitude of the correlation. The results didn't support the Elkind's claim that adolescent egocentrism emerges in early adolescence and decreases linearly throughout middle and late adolescence. In other words, adolescents aged 11 or 12 could experience adolescent egocentrism of the same magnitude as those aged 15 or 16 do. Another study by Frankenberger (2000) also provides evidence that adolescent egocentrism is not age-related.<ref name=Frankenberger2000>{{cite journal|last=Frankenberger, K.D.|title=Adolescent egocentrism: a comparison among adolescents and adults|journal=Journal of Adolescence 2000|date=2000|volume=23|pages=343–354|doi=10.1006/jado.2000.0319}}</ref>
In this study, a survey was conducted for data collection from 223 adolescents and 131 adults. The survey contained measures of three aspects: adolescent egocentrism, self-consciousness, and interpersonal reactivity. The result revealed that scores of egocentrism were not, on average, significantly different between adolescents and young adults (19-30), which indicates that egocentrism in adolescence may continue into adulthood.
===Little association with formal operations=== An important theoretical assumption in Elkind's theory is that the emergence of adolescence egocentrism is a result of the development of formal operational thoughts.<ref name=Elkindeia /> Nevertheless, some studies had findings that were contrast to Elkind's position. Lapsley and his colleagues conducted two studies to examine the theoretical assumptions in 1986.<ref name=Lapsley1986 /> In the second study, they analyzed the data obtained from two samples: a sample of 7th-, 9th-and 11th-graders and another sample of college undergraduate students. They used Adolescent Egocentrism Scale (AES) (Enright et al., 1979, 1980),<ref name=Enright1979 /><ref name=Enright1980 /> Lunzer (1965)<ref name=Lunzer1965 /> formal operations measure and Imaginary Audience Scale (IAS) (Elkind & Bowen, 1979)<ref name=Elkind1979>{{cite journal|last=Elkind, D. |author2=Bowen, R. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Imaginary audience behavior in children and adolescents|journal=Developmental Psychology|date=1979|volume=15|pages=38–44|doi=10.1037/0012-1649.15.1.38 }}</ref> as the instruments.
The result of a grade-by-grade analysis of inter-correlations between adolescence egocentrism and formal operational thoughts showed modest to non-significant differences among all the measures, which implies that there is little association between adolescent egocentrism and formal operations. Some more recent studies got similar findings. Heather et al. (1993) found that formal operations were not an effective indicator of both imaginary audience and personal fable.<ref name=Heather1993>{{cite journal|last=Heather, C.J. |author2=Fredda B. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Formal operation: A test of two models of adolescent egocentrism|journal=Journal of Youth and Adolescence|date=1993|volume=22|pages=313–326|doi=10.1007/bf01537795}}</ref> Galanaki (2012) performed a research to investigate the association of adolescent egocentrism with age, gender, pubertal development and formal operational thoughts.
===Gender differences=== A considerable amount of studies have found gender differences in egocentrism (Smetana, J.G.&VillaLobos M., 2010).<ref name=Maholmes&Lomonaco /> Kimberly A Schonert-Reichl's (1994) study on the relationship between depressive symptomatology and adolescent egocentrism recruited 62 adolescents (30 males, 32 females) aged from 12 to 17. The study used Reynolds Adolescent Depression Scale (RADS),<ref name=Reynolds1987>{{cite book|last=W.M.|first=Reynolds|title=Reynolds adolescent depression scale: Professional manual|date=1987|publisher=Psychological Assessment Resources|location=Odessa, FL:}}</ref> Imaginary Audience Scale (IAS)<ref name=Elkind1979 /> and the New Personal Fable Scale (NPFS)<ref name=LapsleyNPFS>{{cite book|last=Lapsley, D.K. |author2=Rice, K.G. |last-author-amp=yes|title=The "new look" at the imaginary audience and personal fable: Toward a general model of adolescent ego development. In D.K. Lapsley & F.C. Power(eds.), Self, ego, and identity: Integrative approaches|date=1988|publisher=Springer|location=New York|pages=109–129}}</ref> as measuring tools. The results revealed significantly higher scores obtained by females compared with males in the Transient Self subscale in IAS.<ref name=Schonert1994>{{cite journal|last=Schonert-Reichl|first=Kimberly A.|title=Gender differences in Depressive Symptomatology and Egocentrism in Adolescence|journal=The Journal of Early Adolescence|date=1994|volume=14|pages=49–65|doi=10.1177/0272431694014001004}}</ref>
Transient Self, as defined by Elkind and Bowen in 1979, refers to impermanent image of self that is mainly relative to one-time behaviors and temporary appearance.<ref name=Elkind1979 /> Thus, adolescent females have a higher tendency to consider themselves to be different from others, and tend to be more self-conscious in situations that involve momentary embarrassments (e.g. going to a party with a bad haircut), than their male peers.<ref name=Schonert1994 /> Another study conducted by Goossens and Beyers (1992) using similar measuring instruments found that boys have stronger beliefs that they are unique, invulnerable and sometimes omnipotent, which are typical characteristics of personal fable.<ref name=Goossens1992>{{cite journal|last=Goossens, L. |author2=Beyers, W. |last-author-amp=yes |title=The imaginary audience and personal fable: factor analyses and concurrent validity of the "New Look" measures|journal=Journal of Research on Adolescence|date=1992|volume=12 | issue = 2|pages=193–215}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Imaginary audience]] * [[Personal fable]]

'''Applied academics''' is an approach to learning and teaching that focuses on how [[list of academic disciplines|academic subjects]] ([[Communication|communications]], [[mathematics]], [[science]], and basic [[literacy]]) can apply to the real world.<ref name=Hocking> {{cite web|url=http://www.hocking.edu/~aaffairs/GLOSSARY.HTML |title=Glossary |publisher=Hocking College Academic Affairs Department |accessdate=2007-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020206120831/http://www.hocking.edu/~aaffairs/GLOSSARY.HTML |archivedate=February 6, 2002 }} </ref> Further, applied academics can be viewed as theoretical knowledge supporting practical applications.<ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.bced.gov.bc.ca/careers/aa/cfaa-faq.htm#need | title=Frequently Asked Questions about Applied Academics | publisher=Center for Applied Academics | accessdate=2007-05-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070411112813/http://www.bced.gov.bc.ca/careers/aa/cfaa-faq.htm| archivedate= 11 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} </ref><ref name=STEM> {{cite web | url=http://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/Systems_And_Tools_Educational_Model#Definitions | title=Systems and Tools Educational Model | last=Walker | first=Jacob | publisher=Wikimedia | accessdate=2007-05-02|display-authors=etal}} </ref>
== Definition ==
Applied Academics is an approach to learning which focuses on motivating and challenging students to connect what they learn with the world they experience and with what interests them. The basic premise is that if academic content is made more relevant, participatory and concrete, students learn better, retain more and apply learning in their lives. Teaching in this model uses hands-on innovative [[Teaching method|teaching methods]] sometimes called [[contextual learning]]. Teachers help students understand the reasons for studying their subject matter and capitalize on students' natural learning inclinations and problem-solving approaches they can use well beyond the classroom throughout their lives.<ref name="Hocking"/>
Applied Academics is an attempt to break from disconnected learning (where students go to different classes for different subjects for specified periods of time and don't gain a sense of the interconnectedness of [[learning]]) that has become a part of traditional approaches to education. This approach attempts to reintegrate learning by doing such things (for example) as teaching [[Mathematics|math]], [[science]], [[writing]], or speech within other contexts such as a learning experience dealing with some form of technology training.<ref name="Hocking"/>
== Research in cognitive science ==
[[Research]] in [[cognitive science]] has shown that learners are not passive receptacles into which knowledge may be "poured". Learning occurs when the learner constructs, invents, and [[Problem solving|solves problems]]. Studies have shown that students taught theoretical principles, processes and skills in isolation without practice do not transfer these skills and knowledge as well to real life situations. Although "learning to know," "learning to do," and their "application" are often separated, there is no effective learning or understanding of one kind without the other two.<ref> {{cite paper | author = Secretary's Commission on Achieving Necessary Skills | title = Identifying and Describing The Skills Required by Work | date = 1990 | url = http://wdr.doleta.gov/SCANS/idsrw/idsrw.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2007-05-16}} </ref>
==Relating to the SCANS Competencies== In the United States the [[Secretary's Commission on Achieving Necessary Skills]] (SCANS) states that "good jobs require people who can put knowledge to work", and listed the [[knowledge]] ([[Academia|academics]]) that it considered critical for all students to possess.<ref name=SCANS> {{cite paper | author = Secretary's Commission on Achieving Necessary Skills | title = What Work Requires of Schools | date = 1991 | url =http://wdr.doleta.gov/SCANS/whatwork/whatwork.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2007-05-15}} </ref>
These competencies include: * Knowing how to effectively allocate time, money, materials, space, and staff * The ability to work on a team, teach, serve customers, lead, negotiate and work with people from culturally diverse backgrounds * Understanding how to effectively acquire, evaluate, and use data * Understanding and ability to design and improve social, organizational, and technological systems * The ability to effectively use technology
==Relating to action research== The concept of [[action research]] is related to Applied Academics, as one tenet of action research is to discover theory through practice, and then implement using the foundation of theory.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

'''Baby videos''' are educational tools which can be used for teaching [[Baby|babies]] as young as six months by introducing the [[alphabet]], different sights, [[Shape|shapes]] and [[Color|colors]], [[Number|numbers]] and [[counting]]. Baby videos can be used for helping babies learn important educational skills, comprehension, introduction to the environment, as well as [[music]]. Some parents use baby videos to help develop their children's [[motor skills]] and open their young minds to the world. Certain [[Preschool|preschools]], educators and caregivers find baby videos to be a useful tool, but medical professionals have yet to determine whether or not baby videos are beneficial to children or not.
Several baby videos are available on the market today. They include videos which introduce letters, music videos, or videos that teach babies to communicate when they are young such as signing videos.
The biggest benefit of digital media on children is the ability to expose children to the world during their “Why?” phase. Digital media will help explain things to children that parents may not have the ability to.
== History == The earliest forms of entertainment for children were usually meant to be educational. The very first television program that was tailored to children specifically was the [[BBC]]’s [[The Children's Hour (TV program)|''Children’s Hour'']]'','' which was first broadcast in 1946<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/are-you-sitting-comfortably-a-history-of-childrens-tv-1335443.html|title=ARE YOU SITTING COMFORTABLY? A HISTORY OF CHILDREN'S TV|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> The United States followed suit in 1947 by airing [[Kukla, Fran and Ollie|''Kukla, Fran, and Ollie,'']] a show featuring puppets which ran for 10 years''. [[Howdy Doody]]'' and [[Captain Kangaroo|''Captain Kangaroo'']] soon followed, and both ran for over 12 years. The shows that were being broadcast for children were successful, but not necessarily educational. Later on in the 1960’s and 1970’s, television shows for children began to change pace. Not only were the shows being released entertaining and loved by children, but they were also educational. Shows like [[Sesame Street|''Sesame Street,'']] [[Mister Rogers' Neighborhood|''Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood'']]'','' and [[Schoolhouse Rock!|''Schoolhouse Rock!'']] began to gain popularity<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Wartella|first=Ellen|last2=Richert|first2=Rebekah A.|last3=Robb|first3=Michael B.|date=2010-06|title=Babies, television and videos: How did we get here?|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.dr.2010.03.008|journal=Developmental Review|volume=30|issue=2|pages=116–127|doi=10.1016/j.dr.2010.03.008|issn=0273-2297}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Engstrom|first=Erika|date=1995-07|title=Schoolhouse Rock: Cartoons as Education|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01956051.1995.9943695|journal=Journal of Popular Film and Television|volume=23|issue=3|pages=98–104|doi=10.1080/01956051.1995.9943695|issn=0195-6051}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fredrogers.org/fred-rogers/bio/index-test.php|title=Mister Rogers' Neighborhood: A History|website=www.fredrogers.org|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref>. These shows’ target audiences were intended to be children in general without a specific age group.
In 1997 the [[Baby Einstein|Baby Einstein Company]] released its first video ''Baby Einstein''. This was the first educational video targeted specifically to infants. The release of this particular brand of educational videos was very successful, and impactful. The New York Times published in 2003 that 32% of all new babies born in the United States owned a ''Baby Einstein'' video. There was a surge of educational media targeted towards infants and babies after the initial release of ''Baby Einstein''. Television shows such as ''[[Teletubbies]]'' and [[Classical Baby|''Classical Baby'']] were introduced. An entire television network dedicated to infant education called [[BabyFirst|Baby First TV]] was also created<ref name=":0" />.
Thousands of baby oriented educational videos can be found on [[YouTube|Youtube]], teaching lessons about shapes, colors, numbers, etc. to babies specifically. [[Mother Goose Club]] is a [[YouTube|Youtube channel]] devoted to educating infants and toddlers through the use of nursery rhymes. Mobile app developers have also seen the profitability of infant oriented media, and there are now hundreds of mobile applications specifically tailored to educate infants.
== Impact == The educational videos babies are exposed to could actually be harming them. Exposing babies to screens, could take away time that could be used for other things like exploring, interacting, playing, and actively learning <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://zerotofive.net/parenting/pros-and-cons-of-screen-time/|title=Baby TV: Pros and cons of screen time {{!}} Zero to Five|date=2016-07-05|work=Zero to Five|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en-US}}</ref>. During the first two years, babies are beginning to develop intellectual, social, and emotional skills that are needed in life. If used correctly, these videos could possibly benefit a child’s development. Babies are also learning language during the first two years which is a vital part of [[Child development|childhood development]]. Children could develop language skills by watching videos as they will begin to mimic the TV characters who talk to them<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.raisesmartkid.com/pre-natal-to-1-year-old/2-articles/22-the-effects-of-tv-on-baby|title=The Effects of TV on Baby - Raise Smart Kid|date=2015-08-25|work=Raise Smart Kid|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en-US}}</ref>.
Some researchers say that babies rarely benefit from digital media exposure while others say it’s beneficial for their development. In some cases, babies show higher [[vocabulary]] from media. It’s difficult for parents to determine how much their child is actually learning from the videos<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.babycentre.co.uk/a25006035/is-screen-time-good-or-bad-for-babies-and-children|title=Is Screen Time Good or Bad for Babies and Children|last=|first=|date=11-16-2018|website=Baby Centre|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== Criticism == The use of baby videos is not without criticism. Frederick Zimmerman and Dr. Dimitri Christakis of the [[University of Washington]] published a study in 2007 that called the positive learning effect of the videos questionable, and say that they may in fact limit the language learning abilities of toddlers. They claim babies are drawn to the videos due to the rapid scene changes causing an [[orienting reflex]].
Studies have “found that children exposed to educational programs were more aggressive in their interactions.”<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.news.iastate.edu/news/2013/02/18/educationalmedia|title=It may be educational, but what is that TV show really teaching your preschooler? - News Service - Iowa State University|website=www.news.iastate.edu|language=en-us|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> Educational programs are not only introducing young children to pro-education and pro-social goals, but the conflict between characters is often depicted with characters being unkind to each other or using [[Aggression|aggressive]] actions with each other <ref name=":1" />. The research claims that educational programs are by extension teaching these aggressive tendencies that are being shown in conflict development and that the young children are absorbing this information. This means while teaching them conflict resolution the shows are also teaching children how to behave while in a conflict, which in most cases is harsh and unkind.
Another aspect of educational programs focuses on how it takes away from the communicating opportunities between child and parent. A study shows the uses of [[book]] reading, [[toy]] playing, and co-tv viewing to study how well communication between parents and children were conducted. “Although not better than books, toy playing was significantly better than shared TV viewing at encouraging communication”. The study found that tv did not allow for much communication, but when there was communication it was relatively unrelated to what the toddler had asked or said. This is seen as a hindrance to the child’s chance to learn<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/turn-tv/201110/the-real-reason-why-tv-is-bad-the-kids|title=The Real Reason Why TV Is Bad for the Kids|website=Psychology Today|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref>. Educational programs are seen as a hindrance to young children in the aspect of learning due to the poor communication that is had between parent and child.
One study states that “until about age 2, studies show that young children can’t cognitively comprehend what’s being said and retain that information”<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://healthland.time.com/2011/10/18/why-educational-tv-for-babies-doesnt-exist/|title=‘Educational TV’ for Babies? It Doesn’t Exist|last=Rochman|first=Bonnie|work=Time|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US|issn=0040-781X}}</ref>. “[[Television]]-viewing also fosters less parent-child interaction, cutting down on what experts call “talk time,” in which a child hears lots of [[vocabulary]] words that in turn help develop their language abilities”<ref name=":2" />. With no educational value being learned before the age of two and the lack of “talk time” that comes with educational programs this research shows the underside of educational television.

{{about|teacher-related bullying at school|bullying involving lecturers in higher education|Bullying in academia}}
[[School]] [[teacher]]s are commonly the subject of [[bullying]] but they are also sometimes the originators of bullying within a school environment. When an adult bullies a child, it is referred to as psychological, emotional, or verbal abuse.{{by whom|date=September 2018}}
==Incidence== While teacher bullying is recognized as serious and harmful, there are no statistics on either teachers bullying others or teachers being bullied.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bullying Teachers {{!}} Bullying Statistics|url = http://www.bullyingstatistics.org/content/bullying-teachers.html|website = www.bullyingstatistics.org|accessdate = 2015-11-28}}</ref> However, according to one article, a high percentage of teachers admit to bullying students.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Teachers Bullying Students{{!}}No Bullying{{!}}Anti Bullying Help Center|url = http://nobullying.com/high-percentage-of-teachers-admit-to-bullying-students/|website = nobullying.com|accessdate = 2015-11-28}}</ref>
Comprehensive research carried out in the UK found that [[teaching]] was one of the occupations at highest risk from bullying:<ref>Hoel, H. & [[Cary Cooper|Cooper, C.L]]. Destructive Conflict and Bullying at Work, Sponsored by the British Occupational Health Research Foundation, Manchester School of Management, UMIST (2000)</ref> * 15.5% of teachers stating they were currently being bullied * 35.4% saying they had been bullied over the last five years.
In another survey, the [[Economic and Social Research Institute]] found bullying to be more prevalent in schools (13.8pc) than other workplaces (7.9pc).<ref name=Independent>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-197682649.html BULLYING in the staffroom is having a deeply traumatic effect on some teachers and their families, new research reveals.] [[Irish Independent]] April 14, 2009</ref>
Students with learning disabilities may be especially at risk for teacher bullying.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Students with Learning Disabilities at Risk for Teacher Bullying|url = http://www.kidsinthehouse.com/blogs/dr-jennifer-fraser/students-with-learning-disabilities-at-risk-for-teacher-bullying#.VfHcPdbbOII.facebook|website = Kids in the House|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref>
==Complex dynamics== There are complex issues with reporting bullying by teachers, not only for children, but also parents. By means of their position of power over the child, power that enables them to impact the child's present and future,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Teaching Bullies|url = http://www.beakidshero.com/posts/teaching-bullies/|website = Ginger Kadlec: BeAKidsHero™|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref> children and parents are reluctant to report.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Why don’t kids speak up about bullying?|url = http://www.theedadvocate.org/why-dont-kids-speak-up-about-bullying/|website = The Edvocate|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref> There are specific signs that parents should watch for as their child is unlikely to disclose that the teacher is in fact the bully.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 10 Signs That Your Child's Teacher or Coach May Be a Bully|url = http://www.healingwalls.org/10-signs-that-your-childs-teacher-or-coach-may-be-a-bully/|website = Healing Walls|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref>
Furthermore, a teacher who bullies may present as a Jekyll and Hyde figure: he or she is often celebrated and popular so their abuse can go on for long periods of time undetected.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Recognizing the Abusive Coach as Jekyll and Hyde|url = https://jenmfraser.wordpress.com/2015/08/06/recognizing-the-abusive-coach-as-jekyll-and-hyde/|website = Teaching Bullies|accessdate = 2015-11-29|first = Jennifer Fraser|last = PhD}}</ref> Lacking research on teachers in classrooms, once again it is hard to be sure, but certainly in teaching a sport, it can be seen that adults are often rewarded for bullying conduct that would never be tolerated or condoned if done by a child.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Rewarding Adults Who Bully|url = http://www.kidsinthehouse.com/blogs/jenmfrasershawca/rewarding-adults-who-bully|website = Kids in the House|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref>
In a school setting, this is true for teachers in the classroom as well as in their role as coaches of school sports.
Parsons identifies teacher bullying as often being part of a wider [[bullying culture]] within a school, with a complex web of [[Group dynamics|dynamics]] such as:<ref name="Parsons">Parsons L [https://books.google.com/books?id=k_wXp4pUJeQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Bullied+Teacher:+Bullied+Student&hl=en&ei=h7t3TfDvLpGEhQfuy7GBBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Bullied Teacher, Bullied Student: How to Recognize the Bullying Culture in Your School and What to Do About It (2005)]</ref> * Teachers may be bullied by: other teachers, [[students]],<ref>{{cite journal|last=Terry|first=AA|title=Teachers as targets of bullying by their pupils : a study to investigate incidence|journal=[[British Journal of Educational Psychology]]|year=1998|volume=68|issue=2|pages=255–268|url=http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=2351717|doi=10.1111/j.2044-8279.1998.tb01288.x}}</ref> office staff, [[Principal (school)|principals]],<ref>de Wet C [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ891004&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ891004 The Reasons for and the Impact of Principal-on-Teacher Bullying on the Victims' Private and Professional Lives - Teaching and Teacher Education: An International Journal of Research and Studies, Vol 26 No 7 Pages 1450-1459 Oct 2010]</ref> [[school governor]]s or parents * Teachers may bully: other teachers, students<ref>McEvoy A [http://www.stopbullyingnow.com/teachers%20who%20bully%20students%20McEvoy.pdf Teachers Who Bully Students: Patterns and Policy Implications - Hamilton Fish Institute’s Persistently Safe Schools Conference, Philadelphia, September 11-14, 2005] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716145805/http://www.stopbullyingnow.com/teachers%20who%20bully%20students%20McEvoy.pdf |date=July 16, 2011 }}</ref> or parents * Bullying teachers may themselves get bullied by others in turn
==Staffroom bullying== A common manifestation of teacher bullying is [[staffroom]] bullying where teachers are bullied by other teachers or school managers.<ref name=Independent/><ref name=Field>[[Tim Field|Field T]] [http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=365418 Staffroom bullying] [[Times Educational Supplement|The Times Educational Supplement (TES) Magazine]] 21 June 2002</ref><ref>Strickland S [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/bullies-in-the-staff-room-1583254.html Bullies in the staff room] [[The Independent]] 23 November 1995</ref><ref>Dean C [http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=393438 Call to beat the staffroom bullies] [[Times Educational Supplement|The Times Educational Supplement (TES)]] 16 April 2004</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/6165338.stm Being bullied in the staffroom] [[BBC News]] 20 November 2006</ref><ref>McCall B [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2006/nov/20/schools.uk1 Staffroom suffering] [[The Guardian|Education Guardian]], 20 November 2006</ref>
==Manifestations== In investigating teacher bullying, it is important to differentiate a teacher or coach who is demanding versus one who is demeaning. So "yelling" for instance can be highly productive and motivating, but if it involves belittling and is laced with putdowns and swearing, it becomes abusive.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Abuse or motivation? I know it when I see it. Do you? By Matt Davidson, Ph.D., President, Institute for Excellence & Ethics (IEE)|url = http://excellenceandethics.org/blog/2013/04/abuse-or-motivation-i-know-it-when-i-see-it-do-you-by-matt-davidson-ph-d-president-institute-for-excellence-ethics-iee/|website = EXCELLENCE & ETHICS|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref> Bullying by teachers can take many forms in order to harass and intimidate including:<ref>[http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2006/9241594365_eng.pdf?ua=1]</ref> * Swearing, or yelling, especially in close proximity to the child * Using homophobic, sexist,<ref>{{Cite web|title = The use of homophobic slurs in sports: It’s for the athletes’ own good, right?|url = http://www.theedadvocate.org/the-use-of-homophobic-slurs-in-sports-its-for-the-athletes-own-good-right/|website = The Edvocate|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref> racial slurs, or direct personal attacks, comments targeting a child's disability or difference * Humiliating * Berating * Ignoring or shunning * Throwing objects * Raging * Expressing disgust at the child through gestures or facial expressions * Muttering obscenities so only the targeted child or children hear
Bullying of teachers can take many forms in order to [[harass]] and [[intimidate]] including:<ref name="Lepkowska">Lepkowska D [http://www.sec-ed.co.uk/cgi-bin/go.pl/article/article.html?uid=79740;type_uid=1;section=News The shocking stories of teacher-on-teacher bullying] Secondary Education News (SecEd) 11 Nov 2010</ref> * Face-to-face confrontation * [[Memorandum|Memos]] * [[cyber-bullying|Cyberbullying]] (including the use of [[text messaging]] or [[social networking]] sites)
Bullies often exploit positions of seniority over the colleagues they are intimidating (see [[rankism]]) by:<ref name=Lepkowska/> * [[Criticising]] their work * Making unreasonable demands on workload (see [[setting up to fail]]) * [[Sarcasm]] and jokes aimed at the victim * [[social undermining|Undermining]] them by over-ruling their decisions and views
In some cases, teachers are ignored and isolated by colleagues in the staffroom or turned down for [[Promotion (rank)|promotion]] or training courses (see [[silent treatment]]).<ref name=Lepkowska/> Other times, teachers are ostracized as [[whistleblowers]] when they report to administrators on students' reports of bullying being done by their colleagues.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Jennifer Fraser says she left because of a "hostile, humiliating, poisoned or intolerable work environment," created after she complained her son was being abused by teacher coaches. The school says allegations have no basis.|url = https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/04/02/teacher-sues-bc-private-school-alleging-bullying-harassment.html|newspaper = The Toronto Star|date = 2015-04-02|access-date = 2015-11-28|issn = 0319-0781|first = Robert|last = Cribb}}</ref>
==Impacts== The power imbalance of teacher to student is greater than peer to peer and may well intensify the impact. The possible impacts of bullying of teachers include: * [[Victimisation]] and [[victim blaming]]<ref name="Parsons" /> * [[False accusations]] and fabricated [[Discipline#Employment discipline|formal disciplinary action]]<ref>Munday K [http://www.jfo.org.uk/work/sector/teaching.htm The Bullying of Teachers Through the Use of Formal Disciplinary Procedures 2003] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617075239/http://www.jfo.org.uk/work/sector/teaching.htm |date=June 17, 2011 }}</ref> * [[Workplace stress|Stress]] symptoms such as [[anxiety (mood)|anxiety]], [[headaches]], [[nausea]], [[palpitations]], and [[hypertension]]<ref name="Independent" /> * Symptoms of [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) such as a compromised [[immune system]], [[sleep problems]], excessive [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]], [[irritability]], [[hypervigilance]] (which feels like [[paranoia]], but is not), constant anxiety, [[reactive depression]] and [[suicidal thoughts]]<ref name="Field" /> * Loss of [[self-esteem]]<ref name="Field" /> * Loss of job<ref name="Parsons" />
==Notable incidents== In April 2012, Stuart Chaifetz, a father of an autistic boy, released a video on [[YouTube]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tfkscHt96R0 "Teacher/Bully: How My Son Was Humiliated and Tormented by his Teacher and Aide", Stuart Chaifetz, video at YouTube, posted April 20, 2012]</ref> providing evidence that his son was allegedly the subject of emotional abuse at the hands of his teacher and aide at Horace Mann Elementary School, in the [[Cherry Hill Public Schools]] district.<ref>[http://www.horacemannelementary.com/ Horace Mann Elementary School website]</ref> The evidence was secured when Chaifetz wired his son before sending him to school. When he listened to the audio recording, according to one news report, "Chaifetz says he caught his son's teachers gossiping, talking about alcohol and violently yelling at students. He took the audio to the Cherry Hill School District, where officials fired one of the teachers involved after hearing the tape. Chaifetz's son was relocated to a new school, where Chaifetz says he is doing well."<ref>[http://www.myfoxphilly.com/dpp/news/local_news/nj-father-records-teachers-bullying-his-autistic-child NJ Father Records Teachers Bullying His Autistic Child, MyFoxPhilly.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/story/2012-04-29/autism-education-abuse-reform/54616582/1 "Verbal abuse of autistic student sparks calls for reform", Jim Walsh and Phil Dunn, ''Cherry Hill Courier-Post'', reprinted at ''USA Today'' website, 29 April 2012]</ref> However, it appears that students with learning disabilities may be especially at risk for teacher bullying.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Students with Learning Disabilities at Risk for Teacher Bullying|url = http://www.kidsinthehouse.com/blogs/dr-jennifer-fraser/students-with-learning-disabilities-at-risk-for-teacher-bullying#.VfHcPdbbOII.facebook|website = Kids in the House|accessdate = 2015-11-29}}</ref>
In 2011, select members of the Board, the Chaplain and Headmaster at St. Michaels University School were informed that teachers were abusing students in the basketball program. They received an eleven-page document written by a lawyer, who was also a parent of a student at the school, outlining the incidences of "child abuse" occurring on basketball teams at the Senior School. Parents were not informed; teachers remained in position. Although not knowing about this document, throughout the year, at least five families made significant formal complaints to Board members, the Chaplain and Headmaster about the abusive coaching conduct. In 2012, at least thirteen students, at the request of the Headmaster, approved of detailed, written testimonies about the verbal, emotional and some physical abuse they were suffering at the hands of their teachers who were coaching them as a co-curricular.
How they were treated by the Headmaster, the school's Board of Governors, lawyers hired by the school, and educational authorities was the subject of a front-page story by award-winning investigative journalist, Robert Cribb,<ref>{{Cite news|title = In 2012, students at St. Michael’s University School in Victoria — where Steve Nash played basketball — began alleging emotional abuse and humiliation. Did teachers’ behaviour go beyond aggressive coaching?|url = https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2015/03/14/teachers-bullying-scarred-us-say-student-athletes.html|newspaper = The Toronto Star|date = 2015-03-14|access-date = 2015-11-28|issn = 0319-0781|first = Robert|last = Cribb}}</ref> as well as a CTV W5 episode.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Google|url = https://www.google.ca/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&es_th=1&ie=UTF-8#q=youtube%2520smus%2520personal%2520foul&es_th=1|website = www.google.ca|accessdate = 2015-11-28}}</ref> The story was the catalyst for a book, Teaching Bullies: Zero Tolerance on the Court or in the Classroom by Jennifer Fraser, PhD.<ref>{{Cite book|edition = First |title = Teaching Bullies: Zero Tolerance in the Court or in the Classroom|url = https://www.amazon.com/Teaching-Bullies-Tolerance-Court-Classroom/dp/0994082029|publisher = Motion Press|date = 2015-08-08|isbn = 9780994082022|first = Jennifer M. Fraser|last = PhD}}</ref> Fraser's book puts the story in the context of extensive research into the work of psychologists, psychiatrists, and neuroscientists in order to explore the oftentimes taboo subject of Teacher and Coach Bullying.
Informed by research into the serious, extensive, and often irreparable damage to adolescent brains in particular{{fact|date=September 2018}}, Fraser has launched an awareness campaign on Facebook<ref>{{Cite web|title = Teaching Bullies|url = https://www.facebook.com/TeachingBullies/|website = www.facebook.com|accessdate = 2015-11-28}}</ref> and Twitter (@teachingbullies) in an attempt to get lawmakers to put emotional abuse into the criminal code along with sexual and physical abuse. Neuroscientists believe it does similar if not identical harm to developing brains.{{fact|date=September 2018}}
In June 2014, Britain proposed the "Cinderella Law" which would put emotional abuse in the Criminal Code.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Should Emotional Abuse Be Criminalized?|url = http://www.hautlife.com/humans-and-animals/126-humans/humanity/1302-should-emotional-abuse-be-criminalized|website = www.hautlife.com|accessdate = 2015-11-28}}</ref>
==In popular culture== Teachers being portrayed as bullies have made into popular culture, along with works with teachers being bullied by other teachers, students, and even the principal.
=== Films === * ''[[Kids in America (film)|Kids in America]]'', a group of students with help from some teachers tries to stop their bully of a principal from becoming Superintendent, realizing the harm she can cause. * ''[[The Nutty Professor]]'', The School Bully bullies the Professor. * ''[[Matilda (1996 film)|Matilda]]'', based on the [[Matilda (novel)|novel of the same name]], a student with psychokinesis helps her fellow students and a teacher to stop a cruel principal's reign of terror in the school. * ''[[The Breakfast Club]]'', Principal Vernon is often seen as a bully to the students serving detention. * ''[[Mr. Woodcock]]'', the film focuses on a man who is outraged that his former gym teacher, who bullied him and his classmates, is about to become his stepfather. * ''[[A Little Princess]]'', the main character is the target of a corrupt principal at a boarding school. * ''[[The 400 Blows]]'', Antoine Doinel is tormented by his insensitive teacher Guy Decomble. * ''[[Whiplash (2014 film)|Whiplash]]'',<ref>{{imdb title|2582802|title=Whiplash}}</ref> Andrew Neiman is bullied by his abusive teacher Terence Fletcher.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Whiplash: Drum Solo versus Suicide|url = https://jenmfraser.wordpress.com/2015/08/26/whiplash-drum-solo-versus-suicide/|website = Teaching Bullies|accessdate = 2015-11-29|first = Jennifer Fraser|last = PhD}}</ref>
===Books=== * ''[[Harry Potter|The Harry Potter series]]'' features bullying teachers, mainly [[Severus Snape]] and [[Dolores Umbridge]]. * ''[[British comics|British girls' comics]]'' often published bullying teachers and principals in serials and regular strips. Examples can be found in ''Wee Sue,'' ''The Girls of Liberty Lodge'' and ''The Four Friends at Spartan School'', ([[Tammy (comics)|Tammy]]), and ''Hard Times for Helen'' (Judy). ''Patsy and the Beast of Banchester'' (June) reversed the trend to show a teacher being bullied by toughs in her class. ===TV=== * ''[[iCarly]]'': there have been episodes, like "IHave My Principals", where Ms. Francine Briggs and Mr. Howard clearly bully students, including the main characters, one of whom, Sam, is a bully herself. Mr. Devlin and Lauren Ackerman also bullied the students. * ''[[Ned's Declassified School Survival Guide]]'', Mr. Sweeney, a science teacher, appears to be evil until the third season, where he appears to reform himself to the point of saving his students from Vice Principal Harvey Crubbs, who also bullies the students, mainly the main characters. * ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', Coach Bieste is bullied by staff, including [[Sue Sylvester]] and students. * ''[[Home and Away]]'', Casey Braxton is bullied by Mr Dave Townsend in Summer Bay High. * ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode, [[Black-Eyed, Please|Black Eyed, Please]], Lisa is bullied by a jealous substitute teacher, Miss Cantwell. **Later in episode [[Blazed and Confused]], Bart is bullied by his cruel and sadistic new teacher, Mr. Jack Lassen, who shaves off the boy's hair in class. * ''[[Grange Hill]]'' [[List of Grange Hill episodes|(season four, episode four)]] Christopher Stewart is bullied by P.E. teacher Mr. Hicks, to the point of physical injury.
===Music=== * "[[The Happiest Days of Our Lives]]" by [[Pink Floyd]] – song about abusive teachers who are themselves abused by their wives at home.
==See also== * [[Mobbing]] * [[Personality disorders]] * [[School bullying]] * [[School violence]] * [[Sexual harassment in education]] * [[Sexual harassment in education in the United States#Sexual relationships between students and teachers|Sexual harassment and abuse of students by teachers]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== '''Books''' * {{cite book|last=Blase|first=J|title=Breaking the Silence: Overcoming the Problem of Principal Mistreatment of Teachers|year=2003|publisher=Corwin Press|isbn=0-7619-7772-4|author2=JR Blase}} * {{cite book|last=Hart|first=N.|title=Teacher stress: the consequences of harassment and bullying|year=2000|publisher=Monitor|isbn=1-871241-31-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oEe5AAAACAAJ&dq=Teacher+stress:+the+consequences+of+harassment+and+bullying&hl=en&ei=VcR3TbL-B5GwhAevnsWSBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAA|author2=J. Hurd}} * {{cite book|last=Horwitz|first=K.|title=White Chalk Crime: The REAL Reason Schools Fail|year=2008|publisher=Booksurge Llc|isbn=1-4196-9407-3}} * {{cite book|last=Schnall|first=R.S.|title=When Teachers Talk: Principal Abuse of Teachers / The Untold Story|year=2009|publisher=Goldenring Publishing|isbn=0-578-00563-8}}
'''Academic papers''' * {{cite journal|last=Allen|first=K.P.|title=Classroom Management, Bullying, and Teacher Practices|journal=The Professional Educator|date=Spring 2010|volume=34|issue=1|url=http://www.theprofessionaleducator.org/articles/combined%20spring_10.pdf}} * Barnes CA A study investigating the opinions and experiences OF selected teachers regarding teacher bullying - {{Globalize/US|date=September 2018}} [[File:Class Ring.JPG|thumb|A class ring in a ring case. This ring is made of [[white ultrium]] and contains a synthetic [[sapphire]] [[gemstone]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Custom class rings|url=http://www.customringjewelry.com/|website=CR|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref>]] [[File:Damavand College1.jpeg|thumb|[[Damavand College]] class ring of 1975]]
A '''class ring''' (also known as a graduation, graduate, senior, or grad ring) is a [[ring (jewellery)|ring]] worn by [[students]] and [[alumni]] to commemorate their [[graduation]], generally for a [[high school]], [[college]], or [[university]].
Today class rings can be customized, from the material and style that the ring is made of to the color and cut of the gem in the center. There is a wide selection of emblems, pictures, and words that can be added to the sides of the rings and even inside the center gem.
== History ==
The tradition of class rings originated with the class of 1835 at the [[United States Military Academy]] at West Point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usma.edu/publicaffairs/PV/040319/RingMelt.htm|title=Ring melt ceremony bonds past with the future|website= [[United States Military Academy]]}}</ref>
== How to wear == The ''Complete Book of Etiquette'' by [[Amy Vanderbilt]] indicates the following protocol for wearing of a class ring. For as long as the wearer is in school, the insignia should face the wearer to remind him/her of the goal of graduation. Upon graduation, the class ring gains the status of a "badge of honor" similar to a diploma, with the effect that graduation entitles the wearer to display the insignia facing outward so that it faces other viewers. An additional justification for this practice is the rationale that the ring also symbolizes the graduate him/herself: During the wearer's time in school, he or she focuses on self-development and goals specific to the insular academic environment; upon graduation, the wearer enters the wider world and puts what he or she has learned to work in shaping it.<ref>''Complete Book of Etiquette'', [[Amy Vanderbilt]], p. 156</ref>
A notable exception to this protocol is the custom followed by older graduating classes of the [[United States Military Academy]] at [[West Point, New York|West Point]]. Today, as in years past, Academy graduates frequently wear their rings on the left hand in observance of the ancient belief, which also underlay the Anglo-American custom of wearing wedding bands on the left hand, that a [[vena amoris|vein connects the left ring finger to the heart]]. Prior to graduation, these classes wore the USMA Class Ring with the Class Crest closest to the heart, signifying a given cadet's bond to his class within the Academy. Following graduation, members of these classes wore (and, for surviving members, still wear) the ring with the Academy Crest closest to the heart, signifying their bond with the Academy as a whole.<ref>[http://www.west-point.org/family/bicent/rings.html CLASS RINGS, MINIATURES, AND A-PINS] The traditional Jewish custom is to wear a wedding ring on the right index finger, and only women wore them originally. However, most Jewish people will move rings to reflect the national custom of where they live.</ref>
== Ring melt ==
At the [[United States Military Academy]], [[United States Naval Academy]], [[United States Air Force Academy]], [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina|The Citadel]], and the United States Coast Guard Academy each cadet's class ring contains melted gold from rings donated to the respective school from deceased alumni.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Citadel Band of Gold|title=The Citadel Band of Gold|url=http://www.citadel.edu/root/2013-class-ring|website=www.citadel.edu|publisher=The Citadel|accessdate=April 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=West Point Association|title=Class Ring Memorial Program|url=http://www.westpointaog.org/RingMemorialProgram|website=www.westpoint.org|accessdate=April 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=United States Naval Academy Alumni Association and Foundation|title=Bonds of Gold|url=https://www.usna.com/Page.aspx?pid=617|website=www.usna.com|accessdate=January 24, 2017}}</ref>
== In fiction == ''[[The Lords of Discipline]]''. "I wear the ring. I wear the ring and I return often to the city of Charleston, South Carolina, to study the history of my becoming a man." Author [[Pat Conroy]] attended and graduated from [[The Military College of South Carolina|The Citadel]] and wrote the fictional account of a cadet's journey at a military school set in Charleston, South Carolina.
